text: I used jinja2 in django to render a lua file instead of a web page

okay here is a first shot at modules, this example is running the default builder (which is singularity on your local machine). It shows at the end the containers, plus lua files generated for modules (since I have module generation enabled, more likely wanted for cluster admin but just testing now) <https://asciinema.org/a/131576?speed=2>

important question - since the registry is for local users and cluster admins, to what extent do we need an entire web interface? The views I'm making to render in the console seem like they are easier to get to, more efficient, and I'm thinking of dropping the web interface all together
if you go into the collection view you can disable the building and it won't build every commit
can we have options to control build system. This seems to be transparent.

also this would be useful if we can chose different build systems to build our containers, that would mean we can just do a trigger and select the appropriate options rather than just doing a git commit
I understand that rebuilding the container when there is no change is just a waste of time/cpu cycles but having a trigger will be easier then doing a git commit
irrespective of whether you do a commit, the build will be trigger.
so if you have used dockercloud, they have an option to trigger new build which just builds based on latest image tag
I would argue needing to go to a web UI and push build is more tedious than a push to Github
why would you build the same one twice

can't we also have a button "build" container. It should just look at the last commit and pull the information. Instead of doing a git commit --amend to trigger a build is not convenient everytime. I am glad that this works, but we should still have an option to rebuild same container.
how would you want to build? using github to commit and push is a pretty standard workflow
Thats kind of annoying, doing git commit --amend
So it looks like I have to do recommit everytime shub will initiate a build

text: Another option would be to use git branchs system
What I'm trying to think through is if a user's local registry organization should mirror singularity hub, and I think yes, which means a local user would have like

what I'm working on now that is quasi weird is a local registry for a user, because the recipes folder still is going to support a subfolder --> one collection (eg a github repo) with some number of Singularity.label files within it

for both, yes. The difference is that for the first, the image name is derived from the repository and the tags are any level of folder beneath it (and conflicts are decided by using the most recently updated file) and for the second, the image name is the folder/subfolder and then the same tags rule applies for folders beneath that
It would be great !

plain_text: Will it scan any level of subfolder for files  `Singularity.label`

attachments.fallback: [July 19th, 2017 12:02 PM] v: <@U4BKCNE9K> the reason we can do the second for a registry associated with an organization is because we expect them to have one github folder with ALL recipes, meaning the `<username><reponame>` is linked to a `<folder><subfolder>` in one repo, and the namespace for retrieving the image corresponds to `shub://<organization>/<username>/<reponame>`. This also means that files at the root of the repo (eg Singularity as it is now) are ignored for the organization. For the user - the first model (of having tags for a repo allowed anywhere, and subfolders ignored) fits better because the name is already determined by the `<username>/<reponame>`
attachments.text: <@U4BKCNE9K> the reason we can do the second for a registry associated with an organization is because we expect them to have one github folder with ALL recipes, meaning the `<username><reponame>` is linked to a `<folder><subfolder>` in one repo, and the namespace for retrieving the image corresponds to `shub://<organization>/<username>/<reponame>`. This also means that files at the root of the repo (eg Singularity as it is now) are ignored for the organization. For the user - the first model (of having tags for a repo allowed anywhere, and subfolders ignored) fits better because the name is already determined by the `<username>/<reponame>`

text: but I keep going back and forth, first because it would be nice to have the user/organization flow similar, but then the use cases/needs of both are very different

<@U4BKCNE9K> the reason we can do the second for a registry associated with an organization is because we expect them to have one github folder with ALL recipes, meaning the `<username><reponame>` is linked to a `<folder><subfolder>` in one repo, and the namespace for retrieving the image corresponds to `shub://<organization>/<username>/<reponame>`. This also means that files at the root of the repo (eg Singularity as it is now) are ignored for the organization. For the user - the first model (of having tags for a repo allowed anywhere, and subfolders ignored) fits better because the name is already determined by the `<username>/<reponame>`

attachments.title: singularityware/singularity
attachments.text: singularity - Singularity: Application containers for Linux

text: hey everyone! We've added something called "checks" to development --> <https://github.com/singularityware/singularity/tree/development/libexec/helpers#checks> so it's possible to run a series of checks for an image based on an associated tag. The details for how it works is in the link, but I want to encourage everyone to think about how they would want to validate or lint an image, and please contribute checks that would be appropriate to be shipped with singularity

attachments.text: singularity - Singularity: Application containers for Linux

text: the latter would support any level of nesting of a folder, the first allows for more flexibility in putting spec files anywhere you want while still having association with a particular collection

what do people have preference for - if you have a folder (with subfolders) and some number of nested Singularity (recipe) files, let's say we have "science/genomics." Should we ignore subfolder names and go by the Singularity recipe tag (eg, Singularity.gpu is tag gpu) and build collection name science with tag gpu, or should we take subfolder names into account, but build collection name 'science-genomics' with tag gpu?

I guess it would be reasonable to get an error message then. But getting this message:  "ERROR Error downloading None. Do you have permission to write to [current folder]" is somewhat misleading.
it shouldn't include containers that exist (as in objects in the database) that don't yet have an image (file) assigned from storage
this is definitely a bug - I'll fix for the new version
by default it pulls the latest, so what is happening is that the image isn't built yet, so latest is None, and the error is triggered

<@U245DTC59> I will follow your suggestions regarding splitting out the data from that huge container
In the mean time, while working with another (smaller) image, I have noticed the following: If I try to do singularity pull <shub://YeoLab/cellranger> while there is a new build of that container in progress on singularity-hub : I get this error message: "ERROR Error downloading None. Do you have permission to write to [current folder]". This does not seem to be a good description of the actual problem. I do have permission to write in the current folder. As soon as the latest build is complete on singularity hub, I am able to run singularity pull <shub://YeoLab/cellranger>  without a problem. 
Am I missing something ? Should I create a github issue for this ? Thanks!

I think using a single image for a database, one that is HUGE, is probably not the kind of thing singularity hub can really support for logistical reasons - I would advocate for a proper storage strategy for the data, and then perhaps an image to run analysis or control/manage the data
for the `%environment` section, the labels are parsed as is. I think the SINGULARITY prefix is only relevant for runtime
The first is likely the case because I don't even see a folder for this repo in storage.

Finalize image is packaging it to send to the builder, which means compressing it. Depending on how large that is or if that process fails, or if the upload to storage in the cloud fails, that could be what is failing the build.

whewsie! Ok, so `labels` must not be ignored with the comment - you are triggering the warning that the same label is overriding an old one, multiple times, because you have multiple of the same label. That warning is triggered here <https://github.com/singularityware/singularity/blob/master/libexec/python/helpers/json/main.py#L96>. The image is created with the size that you specified, 60,000, because this variable / label is not relevant, at least as far as I can remember :stuck_out_tongue:

Creating and bootstrapping image...

The build went all the way to "finalize the image". I am not sure what comes next. It is not supposed to build a second time since there was a fixed size provided.

Running test scriptlet

[0mTraceback (most recent call last):
File "", line 1, in 
File "/usr/l
Please let me know what you think. Thanks! 
I have a few questions:
- do hash characters (#) not really comment things out in the %labels section
- does the SINGHUB_BUILDER_IMAGE_SIZE variable in he %labels section has some kind of extraordinary powers ?

- variable in the %environment section that starts in SINGULARITY_SOMETHING outside the image become variable SOMETHING when running the image (taht was not a question)
- am i confused, and this "SINGULARITY_" trimming is not related or actually was superseded by the use of the %environment section ?
- is there something similar going on with "SINGHUB_" starting variable in the %labels section ?
- assuming SINGHUB_BUILDER_IMAGE_SIZE has the power of setting the image size for the singularity builder, is is not allowed to have 2 of these settings with different size value in the %environment section ?
- assuming SINGHUB_BUILDER_IMAGE_SIZE has the power of setting the image size for the singularity builder, is there a conflict when the image size is specified twice: once in this manner, and a second time via the singularity hub collection settings form ?
- was that too many questions ? :slightly_smiling_face:
- or one last: in case there is some real issue here, would you like me to copy paste this into the github repo, sorry for flooding this channel, ooops
In the mean time I am going to completely remove the commented SINGHUB_BUILDER_IMAGE_SIZE lines form my Singularity %labels section and try to build again

The algorithm I was thinking of testing is something like:
- User can add Singularity files in any folder, any level of the repo, and any number
- a build is still triggered on commit, and instead of assuming Singularity at base, all Singularity files are checked
 - ONLY those that have a change since the last commit are built - and note this is done by the same builder, so if the user makes changes to 5 files at once, and one of them fails, the build fails that image and keeps going to the others.
- the builder will create a dictionary of images by tag, based on the %label in the spec file `SINGULARITYHUB_TAG`. If it's not defined, `latest` will be used. If there are conflicts (eg, two spec files without tags that would both be latest) a warning is issued and the more recently updated file is used.
- the hub only maintains an image per tag specified by the user. This means that you would only be able to go back in time to an older commit (that you didn't save as a tag) by pushing with that tag again.
but if it's just a field saved in the database, that's not a reproducible thing if the database goes away

so for example, if for a %label field there was SINGULARITYHUB_TAG that would live with the build specification file, and it wouldn't be a big deal if singularity hub exploded, it would rebuild and know to tag that image as such
This must be done in a way that does not rely on saving extra information about the build in singularity hub
"being able to select a branch or tag" that just means having some way to specify what container is built with what tag/branch?

i'd like to see something similar.
- automated builds that happen on pushes (as a choice)
- being able to select a branch or tag, 
   - provide a location for the Singularity file, 
   - the singularity tag name, and 
   - to be able to trigger the builds.
